origin_of_ch_char_book: (å¿ƒ, xin=hsin, heart) Itâ€™s a heart and a blood vessel leading to the heart. Ancient people thought that peopleâ€™s minds or emotions were born in the heart. Therefore, it is used as the meaning of â€˜mindâ€™.,(æ€, si=ssu, think) describes a head with a knot which has a complex thought (x). There is a heart which means emotions in below the character. The ancients believed that human emotions came from the heart, and complex and logical thoughts come from head. This character is a combination of thoughts and emotions that have mixed feelings of mind and soul. (æ„›, çˆ±, ai, love) A person stands tall, with his/her mouth widely opened , breathing long (like Yawning) with heart (å¿ƒ) in it, and with a foot down to the designated place (å¤Š) below. It describes oneâ€™s mind heartily heads to oneâ€™s loved one.
humanum_full_description_en:
Although the shape of the golden seal character of the word " heart " has changed from simple to complex, the orientation of the image is very clear, and they all resemble the shape of the heart. The word "å¿ƒ" was misinterpreted as "è´" in the old oracle bone inscriptions. The two characters are different in shape. The bottom of the word "å¿ƒ" is connected while the word "è´" is separated. See " Bei ".

In the early days, the inscription on the inscription had the shape of a flap in the heart, or added a point in the hollow of the word for decoration. There is another word "æ‚¤" in the inscriptions on the " heart ", which is sometimes mixed. After the Spring and Autumn Period, the bottom pen of the word " heart " became longer and longer, which is the origin of the small seal.

The word " heart " in the oracle bone inscriptions can express the mind, such as "He Ji" 6928: "Wang Youxin (you) heart is Zheng (zheng)", which means that Wang Youxin wants to conquer. In addition, the word "å¿ƒ" can be used as " Qin " to refer to the name of water, such as "He Ji" 14022: "Hexin" refers to crossing the Qin Shui. "Said Wen": "Qin, the water flows out of Shangdang Yangtau Mountain, and enters the river in the southeast." According to Qinshui, it is in the southeast of Shanxi Province today.

" Heart " in the Bronze inscription refers to thoughts and thoughts, like a chime: "Don't (pi) show my imperial examination, but restrain the sacred heart (jue)." The whole sentence praises his great and distinguished father, who has bright thoughts. The ancients believed that love is born in the heart, and that human thinking is also dominated by the heart, "Mencius. "Gao Zi Shang" means: "The official of the heart thinks, thinks you get it, and if you don't think, you can't do it." Therefore, the ancients often used " heart " to express thoughts and feelings. "å¿ƒ" is also the Chinese character with the most word formation possible one.

"Shu Wen": "The heart, the human heart, the soil is hidden in the body. Pictogram. The doctor said that the fire is hidden. All the heart belongs to the heart." Xu Shen explained the five internal organs based on the five elements theory of modern and ancient texts. The ancient Scriptures are based on the heart, while the modern Scriptures are based on the fire.
humanum_short_description_en: " Heart " is the shape of the heart in the golden seal script.

heisig_comment:
* As a primitive, it can take three forms, to which we shall assign three distinct meanings.
In its kanji-form, it appears BENEATH or to the RIGHT of its relative primitive and means th physical organ of the heart.
To the LEFT, it is abbreviated to three strokes, âº–, and means a wildly emotional state of mind.
And finally, at the very BOTTOM, it can take the form âº—, in which case we give it the meaning of a valentine.

Heisig: This character, a pictographic representation of the heart, is among the most widely used primitives we shall meet.
* As a primitive, it can take three forms, to which we shall assign three distinct meanings.
In its kanji-form, it appears BENEATH or to the RIGHT of its relative primitive and means th physical organ of the heart.
To the LEFT, it is abbreviated to three strokes, âº–, and means a wildly emotional state of mind.
And finally, at the very BOTTOM, it can take the form âº—, in which case we give it the meaning of a valentine.

Although the shape of the golden seal character of the word " heart" has changed from simple to complex, the orientation of the image is very clear, and they all resemble the shape of the heart. The word " å¿ƒ" was misinterpreted as " è´" in the old oracle bone inscriptions. The two characters are different in shape. The bottom of the word " å¿ƒ" is connected while the word " è´" is separated. See " Bei". In the early days, the inscription on the inscription had the shape of a flap in the heart, or added a point in the hollow of the word for decoration. There is another word " æ‚¤" in the inscriptions on the " heart", which is sometimes mixed. After the Spring and Autumn Period, the bottom pen of the word " heart" became longer and longer, which is the origin of the small seal. The word " heart" in the oracle bone inscriptions can express the mind, such as "He Ji" 6928: "Wang Youxin (you) heart is Zheng (zheng)", which means that Wang Youxin wants to conquer. In addition, the word " å¿ƒ" can be used as " Qin" to refer to the name of water, such as "He Ji" 14022: "Hexin" refers to crossing the Qin Shui. "Said Wen": "Qin, the water flows out of Shangdang Yangtau Mountain, and enters the river in the southeast." According to Qinshui, it is in the southeast of Shanxi Province today. " Heart" in the Bronze inscription refers to thoughts and thoughts, like a chime: "Don't (pi) show my imperial examination, but restrain the sacred heart (jue)." The whole sentence praises his great and distinguished father, who has bright thoughts. The ancients believed that love is born in the heart, and that human thinking is also dominated by the heart, "Mencius. "Gao Zi Shang" means: "The official of the heart thinks, thinks you get it, and if you don't think, you can't do it." Therefore, the ancients often used " heart" to express thoughts and feelings. " å¿ƒ" is also the Chinese character with the most word formation possible one. "Shu Wen": "The heart, the human heart, the soil is hidden in the body. Pictogram. The doctor said that the fire is hidden. All the heart belongs to the heart." Xu Shen explained the five internal organs based on the five elements theory of modern and ancient texts. The ancient Scriptures are based on the heart, while the modern Scriptures are based on the fire.

heart
Basic explanation of words
heart
xÄ«n
The organ responsible for blood circulation in humans and higher animals (commonly known as the "heart"): the pericardium. Heart rhythm. Heart failure. Palpitations.
Central, hub, main: confidant. center.
It is customary to refer to the organs of thoughts and mental conditions, feelings, etc.: psychology. Heart song. Soul-stirring. Heart. Heart. heartfelt. Refreshing and happy. People's hearts are at stake.

Chinese dictionary definition of words
[â‘ ]ï¼»xÄ«nï¼½
["Guangyun" Xilinqie, flat invasion, heart. ]
(1) Heart. The muscular organs in humans and vertebrates that promote blood circulation.
(2) The location of the heart. Refers to the chest in general.
(3) Refers to the stomach.
(4) The ancients used the heart as the organ of thinking, so it was later used as a synonym for brain.
(5) General term for thoughts, ideas, and feelings.
(6) Caring and caring.
(7) Nature; temperament.
(8) Thinking; planning.
(9) Center, center.
(10) Refers to the spikes, stamens, or bud tips of plants and trees on wood.
(11) Refers to the fillings of certain snacks. Such as steamed bun heart, dumpling heart. See "heart son".
(12) Ancient Chinese philosophical terms. Refers to the subjective consciousness of people. Contrast with "things". Idealist philosophers believe that the "heart" is the noumenon of the world.
(13) Materialist philosophers believe that the "heart" cannot be separated from the "thing". Only when there is a "thing" can there be a "heart", and without a "thing", there is no "heart".
(14) Buddhist language. Contrast with "color". Buddhism refers to all spiritual phenomena as the "heart", which is called the "Three Realms Idealism".
(15) Star name. One of the twenty-eight places, the fifth place of the seven places of the Eastern Canglong, has three stars.
